raw_comment:
I notice that people with lower incomes don't even get a boost when it comes into getting into ivy league colleges those in the 99th percentile get over a 2x boost to their chances, even when not legacy. 

I wonder if there are other factors into someone's admission, whether it be race, country of origin, or even the current school a student is currently attending.

This relates to my community as many people within my school have hopes of getting into ivy league colleges even if their parent(s) have an overall low income.
ace_sentences: I notice a fact about admissions to Ivy League colleges.
People with low incomes do not get a boost in admission chances.
Some people are in the 99th percentile of income.
People in the 99th percentile of income get more than a 2-times boost in admission chances.
Some people are not legacy applicants.
Even if a person is not a legacy applicant, a person in the 99th percentile of income gets more than a 2-times boost in admission chances.
I wonder if other factors affect a person's admission.
Race can be a factor in admission.
Country of origin can be a factor in admission.
The current school of a student can be a factor in admission.
Many people in my school hope to get into Ivy League colleges.
Some parents of these people have an overall low income.
